column2: Whatever5696, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I took this drug for weight loss and to help with studying for college.  When taking any supplements that you may build a tollerane to, you should take some time off from taking it when you begin to build a tollerance.  Any supplement can be addictive so if you have an addictive personallity don't take it.  It's a wonderful supplement that I take off an on for college and or to control my weight.  Drink plenty of water and take in moderation.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: As with ANYTHING, moderation is the key.  If you abuse this drug, OF COURSE it can have potentially negative effects.  I started using this years ago when it was still legal, to lose weight and keep up with my long hours at work as a paramedic.  I lost 45 lbs in a few months and I pretty much loved everything about it. I will tell you that the "negative" side effects I noticed were dry mouth and increased thirst (never let your mouth stay too dry, for too long -- this is how tooth decay begins!), I definitely felt like I had a shorter temper than normal after being on it consistently for approx. 6 months.  This is when I decided to cut back... to once or twice a week, at most.  I can understand why the FDA banned this drug, but at the same time, I think that under a physician's care it can do A LOT of GOOD.  It basically removes your desire to eat... thus helping you lose weight and helping any weight related issues you may have.  It has been proven to drastically aid in the relief of asthma symptoms.  I believe that IF you use this drug in moderation, and fully understand the possible risks, it's a wonderful thing.  Unfortunately, this country is FULL of people who abuse all good things, so you're going to have the bad effects that come with that i.e. Mental issues, stroke, heart attack, etc, etc, etc.  Be smart people!!  All good things can cause damage if you abuse them!

column2: pwt54, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month
chronic cougher, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I originally started taking ephedrin unintentionally while in college, in the form of diet/energy pill as sleep-replacement.  I had no idea what it was, all I knew was that it made me more alert, gave me more energy/strength, and let me pull all nighters.Even when they took it off the shelves, I had no idea what it was or what it did.  I didn't make the connection at the time, but a few months after I stopped taking it, I started developing a chronic cough.  My primary care Dr wrote it off as a cold (for 4 months?).  My ENT wrote it off as post-nasal drip induced.  Finally, after it got progressively worse, a pulminologist determined that my cough was triggered by low grade asthma (which I had as a kid, and "naturally" went away once I started taking ephedrin).  We went through 4 different types of asthma treatments, to varying degrees of success, none satisfactory.Last year, I scored some ephedrin from a guy at the gym, and finally stopped my chronic cough.Within a week after my stash was exhausted, my chronic cough returned.  My "guy" disappeared, and I need more ephedrin!

column2: Cortisone is a dangerous drug, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Have used it as combination medicine 60mg with Doxyllamine succinate 25mg, ambuphylline 180mg, Phenylephrine 25mg continuously for 38 years to manage COPD. My asthma developed into COPD through cortisone treatment in my youth. Ephedrine and derivatives of ephedrine (used in combination with the above)saved my life and my health. Cortisone treatment including simbicort is dangerous and entrenches asthma. I have also done weight training/ body building while on this medication.At age 59 my lung capacity is 17per cent greater than average male of my age and height. The negative comments about ephedrine are ill informed. The medicine improves mental focus and general health. I have six university degrees and professional qualifications. Ephedrine is a miracle medicine.

column2: Roger H, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this medication for over 20 years. What started out as an effective way to increase energy, over time, it took larger amounts in order to have the same effects. Now when taking over 600-800 millagrams a day, it surves little purpose other than help me marginally function with some energy. Without it, I think I would sleep all day long and not have a job. I would not  recommend use of this product to anyone, regardless of how it may start out to serve its purpose, because in the long run, it will make you age faster than normal, not to mention the long term emotional and physical affects.
